history.content:
Maybe you can check out some graduate classes like EE 227C.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

EE 127 is NOT gentle. I have taken math 110 and math 170 (mathematical methods for optimization) and I can see why you find the first month of EE 127 to be easy. However, the reason they spend time on linear algebra is because EE16A/B did a very poor job at teaching linear algebra. After the first month, the class will be much more interesting.

Math 110 is abstract but not necessarily hard. It is useful if you study things like linear system theory (Fourier analysis, differential equations, etc) and quantum mechanics (Hermitian operator, eigenstates). But if you want to learn numerical linear algebra, which is what optimization really relies on, then EE127/227/290 will be useful. Again, there is a difference between numerical linear algebra and abstract linear algebra, which deals with operators potentially in infinite-dimensional spaces instead of matrices.

If you want to learn hardcore proofs of optimization techniques, you can take math 170. You will get Math 104 level proofs on Lagrange multipliers, LP, KKT, Slater's condition, and the calculus of variations, which I don't think are necessary for most people.

Maybe you can check out some graduate classes like EE 227C.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

EE 127 is NOT gentle. I have taken math 110 and math 170 (mathematical methods for optimization) and I can see why you find the first month of EE 127 to be easy. However, the reason they spend time on linear algebra is because EE16A/B did a very poor job at teaching linear algebra. After the first month, the class will be much more interesting.

Math 110 is abstract but not necessarily hard. It is useful if you study things like linear system theory (Fourier analysis, differential equations, etc) and quantum mechanics (Hermitian operator, eigenstates). But if you want to learn numerical linear algebra, which is what optimization really relies on, then EE127/227/291 will be useful. Again, there is a difference between numerical linear algebra and abstract linear algebra, which deals with operators potentially in infinite-dimensional spaces instead of matrices.

If you want to learn hardcore proofs of optimization techniques, you can take math 170. You will get Math 104 level proofs on Lagrange multipliers, LP, KKT, Slater's condition, and the calculus of variations, which I don't think are necessary for most people.
Maybe you can check out some graduate classes like EE 227C

children.subject: You will have minimal luck getting into advanced optimization classes on the graduate level if you don't take 127. Stick with it. It'll be worth it.
Personally I don't think 110 is too abstract for engineering optimization. It will deepen your understanding of lin alg in an axiomatic way if you feel like that helps you.

history.content:
Hey, I'm a CS sophomore interested in optimizations and modelling. Naturally, I thought EECS 127 would be perfect for me; however, it seems like EECS 127 is a very gentle introduction to optimization. We spend the first third of class going over linear algebra. We had a quiz to gauge our lin alg knowledge but everything on it was pretty easy. 

I feel like Math 110 would have been a better course if I just wanted to advance my linear algebra skills -- does anybody know any other optimization alternatives or have advice? Thanks a bunch.
history.subject: EECS 127 Alternatives
